Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Carbonylation Methodologies and Strategies for Complex Natural Product Synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Mingji Dai of the Department of Chemistry at Purdue University is developing new palladium-catalyzed carbonylation methodologies and strategies for the syntheses of bioactive natural products. The goal of this research is to use cheap and abundant carbon monoxide as the starting material to made more advanced and complicated molecular structures with the aid of a small amount of palladium catalyst. These newly developed methodologies and strategies streamline the syntheses of important natural products, which are either organic insecticides or promising lead compounds for drug discovery. This work is expected to advance the science of preparing complicated molecular structures. The project centers on the use of palladium catalysis and extends known methods to complex natural product syntheses. In addition to training postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate students, the educational plan includes outreach to educate Indiana high school science teachers and students about catalysis and natural products, as well as their impact of our everyday lives.

Alkyl-palladium species react readily with carbon monoxide to generate reactive acyl-palladium species. In this project, novel reaction modes are developed to trap these in situ generated acyl-palladium species to construct complex and important structures that are otherwise difficult to access. Specifically, Professor Dai is developing (i) palladium-catalyzed tandem alkoxycarbonylative macrolactonization to synthesize tetrahydropyran/tetrahydrofuran-containing bridged macrolides with anticancer activity, (ii) palladium-catalyzed carbonylative Heck macrolactonization to synthesize fused macrolides with insecticidal activity, and (iii) palladium-catalyzed C-C bond cleavage carbonylative lactonizations to synthesize oxaspirolactones with potent activity against drug resistant bacteria. The synthetic applications have the potential impact to combat human diseases and improve agricultural food production. The research is well suited to the education and training of a diverse group of students and scholars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Natural products have been playing important roles in our daily life. Many important medicines and agrochemicals are either natural products or their derivatives. Macrocyclic, spirocyclic, and other polycyclic lactone molecules are privileged members of natural products, from which antibiotics, anti-viral drugs, chemotherapeutic agents, immunosuppressants, and insecticides have been identified. However, many of these molecules are difficult to access due to their natural scarcity and challenging to synthesize because of their structural complexity, which significantly hamper their further development in various important applications. Therefore, there is a great need of new synthetic methodologies and strategies toward these molecules and their analogs. The scientific goal of this project was to discover and develop new palladium-catalyzed carbonylation strategies and methodologies to streamline the synthesis of important natural products containing macrocyclic, spirocyclic, and other polycyclic lactones. The educational goal was to synergistically integrate research in palladium-catalyzed synthetic methodology development and complex natural product synthesis into the education and mentoring of the next generation of chemists from diverse backgrounds. During the course of this NSF support, a collection of novel and enabling palladium-catalyzed carbonylation reactions were developed to prepare macrocyclic and polycyclic lactones. These new carbonylation methodologies use cheap and abundant carbon monoxide as a one-carbon linchpin to efficiently stitch relatively simple starting materials into complex structures with significantly enhanced value in just one step with the help of palladium catalysts. These methodologies are important tools for chemists to create useful molecules for various applications. These methodologies have been used as key steps in synthesizing a collection of natural products. A few examples were highlighted here. (i) A novel tandem palladium-catalyzed Heck carbonylative macrolactonization was developed to synthesize fused-macrolides, which enabled a highly convergent, concise and flexible total synthesis of spinosyn A, the major component of spinosad. Spinosad is an important organic insecticide widely used in agriculture around the world for the control of a variety of insect pests. However, serious insect cross-resistance has been observed for spinosad. The synthetic approach developed under the NSF support provides a new avenue to access important spinosyn A analogs with the potential to target the observed cross-resistance and extend the usage life of this type of important insecticide. (ii) A palladium-catalyzed hydrocarbonylative lactonization strategy was developed to synthesize abiespiroside A, beshanzuenone C, and beshanzuenone D. The latter two were isolated from the critically endangered Chinese fir tree species Abiesbeshanzuensis. There are only three such trees left in the world and they are among the top 12 most endangered plants of the world. The synthesis developed under the NSF support not only established a sustainable supply of these molecules, but also led to new analogs and probe molecules, from which a selective covalent inhibitor of the oncogenic protein tyrosine phosphatase SHP2 was identified. The probe molecules also led to the identification of DNA polymerase epsilon subunit 3 (POLE3) as one of the cellular targets of the beshanzuenones via a chemoproteomics approach. It was demonstrated for the first time that targeting POLE3 with a small molecule is a novel strategy for chemosensitizing cancer cells to DNA damaging drugs such as etoposide. (iii) A series of palladium-catalyzed hydroxycyclopropanol ring-opening carbonylative lactonization reactions and copper-catalyzed hydroxycyclopropanol ring-opening cyclization or cross coupling reactions were developed as well. These novel hydroxycyclopropanol ring-opening reactions have been used to facilitate the total syntheses of important bioactive natural products including α-levantanolide, α-levantenolide, bisdehydroneostemoninine, bisdehydrostemoninine, tuberostemoamide, sessilifoliamide A, paeonilide, and hyperiones A and B. Finally and importantly, the project provided valuable and strong training for undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs associated with this NSF support and helped them to improve their performance, skills, and attitudes. New teaching materials have been developed and disseminated to Indiana high school teachers to educate Indiana high school students and help attract more students to the STEM field.


Last Modified: 07/26/2021
Modified by: Mingji Dai
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Natural products have been playing important roles in our daily life. Many important medicines and agrochemicals are either natural products or their derivatives. Macrocyclic, spirocyclic, and other polycyclic lactone molecules are privileged members of natural products, from which antibiotics, anti-viral drugs, chemotherapeutic agents, immunosuppressants, and insecticides have been identified. However, many of these molecules are difficult to access due to their natural scarcity and challenging to synthesize because of their structural complexity, which significantly hamper their further development in various important applications. Therefore, there is a great need of new synthetic methodologies and strategies toward these molecules and their analogs. The scientific goal of this project was to discover and develop new palladium-catalyzed carbonylation strategies and methodologies to streamline the synthesis of important natural products containing macrocyclic, spirocyclic, and other polycyclic lactones. The educational goal was to synergistically integrate research in palladium-catalyzed synthetic methodology development and complex natural product synthesis into the education and mentoring of the next generation of chemists from diverse backgrounds. During the course of this NSF support, a collection of novel and enabling palladium-catalyzed carbonylation reactions were developed to prepare macrocyclic and polycyclic lactones. These new carbonylation methodologies use cheap and abundant carbon monoxide as a one-carbon linchpin to efficiently stitch relatively simple starting materials into complex structures with significantly enhanced value in just one step with the help of palladium catalysts. These methodologies are important tools for chemists to create useful molecules for various applications. These methodologies have been used as key steps in synthesizing a collection of natural products. A few examples were highlighted here. (i) A novel tandem palladium-catalyzed Heck carbonylative macrolactonization was developed to synthesize fused-macrolides, which enabled a highly convergent, concise and flexible total synthesis of spinosyn A, the major component of spinosad. Spinosad is an important organic insecticide widely used in agriculture around the world for the control of a variety of insect pests. However, serious insect cross-resistance has been observed for spinosad. The synthetic approach developed under the NSF support provides a new avenue to access important spinosyn A analogs with the potential to target the observed cross-resistance and extend the usage life of this type of important insecticide. (ii) A palladium-catalyzed hydrocarbonylative lactonization strategy was developed to synthesize abiespiroside A, beshanzuenone C, and beshanzuenone D. The latter two were isolated from the critically endangered Chinese fir tree species Abiesbeshanzuensis. There are only three such trees left in the world and they are among the top 12 most endangered plants of the world. The synthesis developed under the NSF support not only established a sustainable supply of these molecules, but also led to new analogs and probe molecules, from which a selective covalent inhibitor of the oncogenic protein tyrosine phosphatase SHP2 was identified. The probe molecules also led to the identification of DNA polymerase epsilon subunit 3 (POLE3) as one of the cellular targets of the beshanzuenones via a chemoproteomics approach. It was demonstrated for the first time that targeting POLE3 with a small molecule is a novel strategy for chemosensitizing cancer cells to DNA damaging drugs such as etoposide. These novel hydroxycyclopropanol ring-opening reactions have been used to facilitate the total syntheses of important bioactive natural products including α-levantanolide, α-levantenolide, bisdehydroneostemoninine, bisdehydrostemoninine, tuberostemoamide, sessilifoliamide A, paeonilide, and hyperiones A and B. Finally and importantly, the project provided valuable and strong training for undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs associated with this NSF support and helped them to improve their performance, skills, and attitudes. New teaching materials have been developed and disseminated to Indiana high school teachers to educate Indiana high school students and help attract more students to the STEM field.
